subject: PRE-MARKET JAPANESE & SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Germany is to stockpile millions of doses of Fujifilm's anti-flu drug Avigan
content:
JAPAN

ABC-MART (2670 JT) - Co. March same store sales fell 29.9% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Fujifilm Holdings (4901 JT) - Germany is to stockpile millions of doses of Co.’s anti-flu drug Avigan. (Newswires)

Japan Post Bank (7182 JT) - Co. is said to reduce rates on term deposits effective today. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Motors (7211 JT) - Co. announced temporary output suspension at its Japanese plant due to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

Obic (4684 JT) - Co. May report FY. Oper. Profit rose 13% Y/Y to around JPY 43bln. (Newswires)

Toshiba (6502 JT) - Co. denies reports which suggested it is applying for Tokyo Stock Exchange 1st Section listing. (Newswires)

United Arrows (7606 JT) - Co. March same store sales fell 24.2% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News Japan’s coronavirus package will include JPY 100bln in SME loans, while other reports also noted the government is to offer JPY 100bln in financial support to large companies through the Development Bank of Japan. (Newswires/Nikkei)

Japan FSA is said to ease write-down rules for cross shareholders. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005390 KS) - Co. has been placed on the negative watchlist by S&P. (Yonhap)

Other News - US official denied report that a US-South Korea defence sharing cost agreement was reached, while the official noted negotiations are ongoing to ensure a mutually beneficial deal. (Yonhap)

Data Recap - South Korea Foreign Reserves (USD)(Mar) 400.2B (Prev. 409.2B). (Newswires)

subject: US President Trump says we are in a critical phase in our war against coronavirus and we are going to save a lot of American lives
New York Mayor De Blasio urges residents to wear face coverings in public to prevent spread of coronavirus
JPMorgan Chase (JPM) says it may not be ready for the Small Business Administration payment protection program by tomorrow
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US CDC said COVID-19 cases rose 14.5% to 213,144 (prev. +14% at 186,101), death toll rose 25% to 4,513 (prev. +26% to 3,603). (Newswires)

US President Trump, under the DPA, issues an order to the administration to use all authorities to support the supply of materials for making ventilators to six companies which include General Electric (GE), Medtronic (MDT), Hill-Rom Holdings, Resmed, Royal Philips and Vyaire Medical. (Newswires)

US expects to begin making payments to Americans under the USD 2tln relief package in mid-April, although some people without direct deposit information may not receive checks until mid-August or later, according to a memo. (Associated Press)

UK Health Official Newton said he has been told the first result of an antibody test of a random sample of the UK population will be available in the upcoming days. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

Japanese government is to offer JPY 100bln in financial support to large companies through the Development Bank of Japan. (Nikkei)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson's spokesman said there are currently no talks on extending the Brexit transition period and noted that if further steps are needed on lockdown, we will do so. The spokesman added they will not be assessing the lockdown before Easter but the government will set out its position afterwards. (Newswires)

EU Commission proposed borrowing EUR 100bln against EU government guarantees to finance the EU short-time work scheme, according to a document. There were also comments from EU Commission President Von der Leyen said that the government heads she spoke to are interested and positive in regards to the short-term work proposal, while she added the EUR 100bln short-term scheme is a massive support. (Newswires)

EU's Economics Commissioner Gentiloni stated that annual GDP growth will decline by 3% each month in a lockdown. And that there are no discussions regarding a bailout for Italy. (Newswires)

French Finance Minister Le Maire said Europe should utilise all means available in response to the virus, while he added that they should use ESM with light conditionality and no stigma attached; he favour activating new financing from EIB for EUR 200bln. (Newswires)

Germany Economy Minister Altmaier said in some months of H1 2020, the economy will contract by more than 8%. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US President Trump said he spoke to President Putin yesterday and Saudi Crown Prince today and expects them to announce an oil production cut of 10mln-15mln BPD. Furthermore, Trump also tweeted that he spoke to the Saudi Crown Prince who spoke with Russian President Putin, although Russian Kremlin spokesperson Peskov stated that President Putin has not spoken to the Saudi Crown Prince. (CNBC/Newswires)

US administration official said the US doesn't know formal details of Saudi and Russian plans to cut oil supply and that US President Trump doesn't plan to ask domestic producers to agree on a specific cut. The official also commented that the US cannot orchestrate a mandated domestic oil supply cut and that US companies are already cutting production as they run out of storage space, while the US government is considering suspending royalty payments on oil production to support domestic suppliers. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia is said to be calling for an emergency OPEC+ meeting and aims to reach a fair oil agreement to stabilise the oil market. There were also reports that a Saudi official reportedly stated a best case scenario would be, maybe a 6mln BPD cut, while the official added he is not sure how President Trump reached those figures or which countries he has in mind. Furthermore, Saudi Arabia was reportedly considering an oil output cut beneath 9mln BPD if others were to join in and wants other producers such as the US, Canada, Mexico and others in G20 to take part in any cuts, according to WSJ reporter citing sources. (Newswires/WSJ)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said the current oil price is not satisfying for anyone and that US and Russia agreed on measures to stabilise the oil market, while he added it is wrong for Russia to raise production now and oversupply remains. Novak also stated Russia can survive through a period of low oil prices and that OPEC+ cannot counter the declining demand on its own but noted that one of the options is to return to talks with Saudi. (Newswires)

Texas Railroad Commissioner Sitton tweeted that he had a great conversation with Russia's Energy Minister Novak in which they both agreed COVID-19 requires an unprecedented level of international cooperation and that they "Discussed 10mbpd out of global supply.". (Newswires)

US Department of Energy announced it is offering oil producers the option to lease space to store oil in the SPR, in fitting with source reports earlier in the week and is to lease space for 30mln bbls of oil. (Newswires)

Iraq is confident that OPEC+ will reach a positive agreement at its next meeting. (Newswires) 

 

US

Fed's Kaplan (voter, dove) said he is expecting a severe Q2 contraction, as well as some negative GDP in Q3 and then a rebound. (Newswires)

US Initial Jobless Claims w/e 6648k vs. Exp. 3500.0k (Prev. 3283.0k, Rev. 3307k). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Stocks were choppy on Thursday, catching upward momentum in the US session that was induced from the spike higher in crude oil prices (which printed their largest one day move higher at settlement) on comments from President Trump, who said he believes Saudi and Russia will work out 10-15mln bbl production cut. Note that the peak equity gains were relatively modest anyhow, trading around 2% higher at their magnum, which prior to COVID-19 outbreak would raise eyebrows, although with the VIX above 50 and off the back of days with >4% moves, the strength felt more tamed. Stocks were choppy on Thursday, catching upward momentum in the US session that was induced from the spike higher in crude oil prices (which printed their largest one day move higher at settlement) on comments from President Trump, who said he believes Saudi and Russia will work out 10-15mln bbl production cut. Note that the peak equity gains were relatively modest anyhow, trading around 2% higher at their magnum, which prior to COVID-19 outbreak would raise eyebrows, although with the VIX above 50 and off the back of days with >4% moves, the strength felt more tamed. SPX +2.26% at 2526, NDX +2% at 7636, DJIA +2.15% at 21,395.

The TPLEX was little changed amid a choppy session, albeit tight ranges. Futures spiked higher overnight on the announcement the Fed would be suspending USTs and Federal Deposits from the supplementary leverage ratio, supporting banks in maintaining onto Treasuries, although faded the move during APAC trade. Furthermore, similar to Wednesday’s tape action, the complex was sold into the afternoon where the Fed resumed its Treasury purchases, albeit at a smaller clip of USD 60bln per day (down from USD 75bln), which was likely an influencing factor behind the higher offer-to-cover ratios; a crude spike induced rally in equities likely supported the offer in Treasuries too. Note the curve sold off in a steepener fashion after the Fed carried out its long-end purchases first, as it has been doing in prior sessions, before moving up the curve. The corporate issuance bonanza continued with around ten IG issuers coming to the dollar market, including a USD 19bln 5-parter (5s, 7s, 10s, 20s, 30s) for its Sprint (S) merger. Signs of a healthier corporate debt market have been felt at the front-end too, where the NY Fed noted AA-rated CP spreads continue to decline; the USD 3-month FRA-OIS spread narrowed by 8bps to 113bps on the session. Looking at the T-Curve at settlement, yields were little changed, with yields within 2bps higher/lower. T-note (M0) futures settled 3 ticks lower at 138-28+.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 2 April 2020: Record oil price spike after Trump talks of large OPEC+ deal
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries flat, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • REARVIEW: Trump says Saudi/Russia will cut production by 10-15mln bbls; 6.65mln US jobless claims; USTs  and Federal Deposits removed from banks’ leverage ratio; EU Commission proposes EUR 100bln lending  package.
  • COMING UP: Data: Australian Retail Sales, Chinese Caixin Services PMI, EZ, UK & US Composite and Services  PMI (Final), US Labour Market Report & ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI

2 April 2020: Record oil price spike after Trump talks of large OPEC+ deal

MARKET WRAP

Stocks were choppy on Thursday, catching upward momentum in the US session that was induced from the spike higher in crude oil prices (which printed their largest one day move higher at settlement) on comments from President Trump, who said he believes Saudi and Russia will work out 10-15mln bbl production cut. Note that the peak equity gains were relatively modest anyhow, trading around 2% higher at their magnum, which prior to COVID-19 outbreak would raise eyebrows, although with the VIX above 50 and off the back of days with >4% moves, the strength felt more tamed. Meanwhile, BofA was the latest to slash its S&P 500 targets, suggesting it could take multiple years to recover lost corporate earnings: SPX year-end PT cut to 2,600 from 3,100 and 2020 EPS forecast cut to 115 Dollars from 138. The overall risk picture, as gauged by major assets, was slightly ambiguous, where equities and oil were bid, but so was gold, rising around 30 bucks back above USD 1,600/oz, while the Treasury curve was little budged. The data continues to paint a grim scenario too, with jobless claims making another weekly record figure, doubling to in excess of 6mln, while the NY ISM Business Index fell to a record low 12.9 (prev. 51.9), although attention now draws to the US NFP report on Friday (click here for the full Newsquawk preview).

CASE COUNT

WORLDWIDE CASES 1,005,507, DEATHS 51,606, RECOVERED 210,519.

Figures provided as of Thursday (via worldometer website) against Wednesday:

·        US total cases 238,556 (prev. 215,003), death toll 5,741 (prev. 1,049).

·        ITALY total cases 115,242 (prev. 110,574), death toll 13,915 (prev. 13,155).

·        SPAIN total cases 110,238 (prev. 104,118), death toll 10,096 (prev. 9,387).

·        GERMANY total cases 84,636 (prev. 77,981), death toll 1,099 (prev. 931).

·        CHINA total cases 81,589 (prev. 81,554), death toll 3,318 (prev. 3,312).

·        FRANCE total cases 59,105 (prev. 56,989), death toll 4,503 (prev. 4,032).

·        UK total cases 33,718 (prev. 29,474), death toll 2,921 (prev. 2,352).

·        SWITZERLAND total cases 18,827 (prev. 17,768), death toll 536 (prev. 488).

·        NETHERLANDS total cases 14,697 (prev. 13,614), death toll 1,339 (prev. 1,173).

·        CANADA total cases 11,118 (prev. 9,731), death toll 134 (prev. 114).

·        SOUTH KOREA total cases 9,967 (prev. 9,887), death toll 169 (prev. 165).

Note figures are provided via worldometers thus there may be some discrepancies on figures provided against those stated from individual states.

 

 

CRUDE

SETTLEMENT: WTI (K0) SETTLED USD 5.01 HIGHER (+24.67%) AT USD 25.32/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLED USD 5.20 HIGHER (+21.02%) AT USD 29.94/BBL

Oil spiked higher by as much as 40% at one moment, supporting the equity complex too, after US President Trump tweeted that he spoke to the Saudi Crown Prince who spoke with Russian President Putin, saying, "I expect & hope that they will be cutting back approximately 10 Million Barrels, and maybe substantially more". Note that Trump followed up the tweet saying the cut could be as much as 15mln bbls, although it is worth noting he did not specify the time frame, i.e. per day/week/month… A Russian Kremlin spokesperson followed up the remarks saying that Putin had not spoke to the Saudi Crown Prince. However, Saudi press reported that, at the request of Trump, the Kingdom is calling for an emergency OPEC+ meeting in efforts to reach a fair oil agreement to stabilise the market. WSJ sources also reported that Saudi is mulling an output cut beneath 9mln BPD if others were to join in; adding that it wants other producers, such as the US, Canada, Mexico and others in G20 to take part in any cuts. A Saudi official, as cited by the WSJ, said the “best-case scenario would be, maybe a six-million-barrels-a-day cut… I’m not sure how he reached those figures or which countries he has in mind.” Furthermore, a US administration official later said the US does not know formal details of Saudi/Russian plans to cut supply and that Trump is not planning on asking domestic producers to agree on a specific cut, highlighting that producers are already cutting output as they run into storage capacity. However, Trump’s remarks gained some added credence after the Texas Railroad Commissioner Sitton tweeted that he had a great conversation with Russia's Energy Minister Novak, where both agreed COVID-19 requires an unprecedented level of international cooperation and that they "Discussed 10mbpd out of global supply"; adding that he looks forward to speaking with Saudi Prince Abdulaziz Bin Salman soon. Overnight, Trump said he thinks Saudi and Russia will make a deal, possibly within a few days, regarding oil production and suggested that he may know how to solve it. The DoE, as previously suggested, announced it will be offering oil producers the option to lease space in the SPR, initially 30mln bbls worth of space but with intention to increase that by another 47mln bbls (which would mark full capacity); DoE expects the first crude deliveries to occur in late April or early May. Meanwhile, global storage capacity draws closer where Africa storage tanks are reportedly reaching their tops amid the flood of supply to the market, while separate industry sources suggest that oil traders are storing as much as 80mln bbls of oil on tankers at sea. China announcing it is to begin purchasing oil for state reserves will provide some relief.

NORTH AMERICA

STIMULUS: Treasury Department said US Social Security recipients will automatically receive coronavirus economic impact payments, while there were separate reports that the Treasury is planning to hire Wall St advisors to advise on providing aid to the airline sector from the recently approved USD 2tln stimulus bill. Meanwhile, sources have suggested top US banks have threatened to forgo the government’s small-business rescue programme due to concerns of financial and legal risk associated with it. Regarding a part 4 stimulus bill, House Minority Leader McCarthy said it is too soon to be discussing such currently; note that Republican lawmakers have expressed caution in moving ahead to the next bill, instead opting for focus to ensure the recently passed bill feeds through to the economy.

GEOPOLITICS: The Trump administration is reportedly tightening rules to stop China from obtaining its advanced tech for commercial use, before diverting it to military use, according to sources.

CENTRAL BANKS

FED: In its latest stimulus efforts, the Fed has exempted US Treasury debt and Federal Reserve deposits from banks’ supplementary leverage ratio for one year as it seeks to ease strains in Treasury market and boost banks' ability to provide credit – the Fed estimates the latest proposal should free up USD 76bln. It is widely considered that one of the strains limiting credit availability, and a reason behind the “repo madness” in September, is banks’ unwillingness to lend due to regulatory requirements around the balance sheet, such as the leverage ratio, thus exempting some collateral from the requirement will reduce the strain on banks associated with lending.

REST OF WORLD

EUROPEAN STIMULUS: EU Commission proposed borrowing EUR 100bln against EU government guarantees to finance the EU short-time work scheme, according to a document and in line with prior reports. The document urged a quick resolution on a new long-term budget that would support the recovery from epidemic effects; stated that there will be no national co-financing requirement for any of the EU's cohesion funds. Subsequently, EU Commission President Von der Leyen said that the Gov't heads she spoke to are interested and positive in regards to the short-term work proposal, adding that the EUR 100bln short-term scheme is a massive support; said the invention of new tools would take too long to agree among member states for use in the current crisis. Meanwhile, French Finance Minister Le Maire said Europe should utilise all means available in response to the virus, adding that it should use ESM with light conditionality and no stigma attached; he favours activating new financing from EIB for EUR 200bln. The EU's Economics Commissioner Gentiloni stated that annual GDP growth declines by 3% each month in a lockdown and said there are no discussions regarding a bailout for Italy.

UK: A source familiar with discussions said the worst case scenario envisages COVID-19 death toll of 50k if self-isolation is not fully adhered to but the UK is not currently on that path; see April 12th as worst day for deaths, with best case scenario for deaths to keep below 20k.

DATA

WEEKLY JOBLESS CLAIMS for the week ending 28th March rose to a fresh record high 6.648mln, around double last week’s tally which was in itself a record high. The latest spike in jobless claims will not have an impact on the BLS data; in the corresponding survey period for the BLS data, initial jobless claims rose from 211k to 282k. But ahead, the data signals April’s Employment Situation Report will be grim, given accelerating claims; and ahead, analysts are not convinced the peak is in yet. Total layoffs between the March and April payroll surveys look destined to reach perhaps 16-to-20mln, according to Pantheon Macroeconomics, which would be consistent with the unemployment rate rising to 13- to-16%. “We have consistently argued from the beginning that the USD 2trln CARES Act is nothing like big enough; these data, and the numbers which will follow, make another huge package inevitable,” Pantheon said. Click here for tomorrow’s NFP preview.

NY ISM BUSINESS INDEX: The index fell to a record low of 12.9 in March from 39 in April as the coronavirus pandemic shut down the economy given New York is the worst affected area in the US. The six-month outlook fell 15.9 points to 37.9 but is not quite at a record low as the November 2008 print fell to 31 and Feb 09 saw it at 33. ISM highlights the sub index has been a reliable short run guide for current business conditions over time. Elsewhere, employment came in at 36.7, the lowest since September 2016. Quality of purchases hit a 10+year low at 32.7; July ‘09 saw 31.8. Both top line and forward revenue guidance fell to record lows (the metrics were added in 2012), current revenues fell 29.7 points to 28.6 and expected revenues fell 11.1 points to 38.9. Prices paid, the least affected in the March report, fell 4.2 points to 50.0, the breakeven point.

FIXED INCOME

TREASURY SETTLEMENT: T-NOTE (M0) FUTURES SETTLED 3 TICKS LOWER AT 138-28+.

The TPLEX was little changed amid a choppy session, albeit tight ranges. Futures spiked higher overnight on the announcement the Fed would be suspending USTs and Federal Deposits from the supplementary leverage ratio, supporting banks in maintaining onto Treasuries, although faded the move during APAC trade. Furthermore, similar to Wednesday’s tape action, the complex was sold into the afternoon where the Fed resumed its Treasury purchases, albeit at a smaller clip of USD 60bln per day (down from USD 75bln), which was likely an influencing factor behind the higher offer-to-cover ratios; a crude spike induced rally in equities likely supported the offer in Treasuries too. Note the curve sold off in a steepener fashion after the Fed carried out its long-end purchases first, as it has been doing in prior sessions, before moving up the curve. The corporate issuance bonanza continued with around ten IG issuers coming to the dollar market, including a USD 19bln 5-parter (5s, 7s, 10s, 20s, 30s) for its Sprint (S) merger. Signs of a healthier corporate debt market have been felt at the front-end too, where the NY Fed noted AA-rated CP spreads continue to decline; the USD 3-month FRA-OIS spread narrowed by 8bps to 113bps on the session. Looking at the T-Curve at settlement, yields were little changed, with yields within 2bps higher/lower.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +2.26% at 2526, NDX +2% at 7636, DJIA +2.15% at 21,395.

SECTORS: Energy +9%, Utilities +8.2%, Consumer Staples +2.9%, Health Care +2.8%, Financials +2.47%, Technology +2.28%, Communication Services +1.82%, Materials +1.5%, Industrials +1.46%, Real Estate +1.34%, Consumer Discretionary +0.35%

STOCK SPECIFICS: Walgreens (WBA) saw an EPS beat, although revenue and US Pharmacy SSS fell short of estimates. WBA CFO later stated the co. is to defer some investments, adding some strong sales have slowed and are now declining but it will continue with its share repurchase programme and has no plan to cut its dividend. Amazon (AMZN) had an EU court rule in its favour that it is not responsible for trademark violations on its Marketplace platform. Boeing (BA) CEO announced the company has initiated voluntary layoffs to respond to current market conditions, allowing employees to exit with some benefits, adding it will continue to drive the safe return to service of the 737 MAX. Boeing (BA) also stated it will continue to deliver on its commercial, defense and space programs and it will be able to meet customer commitments. Ford (F) Q1 total sales fell 12.5% to 516.300 vehicles. General Electric (GE) Aviation is to lay off 50% of its engine manufacturing staff amid COVID-19 weighing on business. Walmart (WMT) has put its sale of its majority stake in UK's Asda on hold as coronavirus upends the grocery industry. Spruce Point announced its new short position is WD-40 (WDFC). The Information reported Uber (UBER) and Lyft (LYFT) rides are -50% Y/Y amid the coronavirus. Luckin Coffee (LK) are -75% after it announced it has formed a special committee to oversee an internal investigation which found its COO fabricated sales of the financial statements for FY19. Zoom Video (ZM) announced its daily users hit a new record of 200mln, up from the previous record of 10mln.

FOREX

DXY: The dollar index saw a choppy trade. Initial weakness in the morning was pared, with the DXY rising to highs at 100.180 prior to the jobless claims data (which spiked to 6.6mln), which resulted in some initial USD weakness. The reversal post data continued as US President Trump announced he expects a 10-15mln BPD oil production from Russia and Saudi after speaking to the Saudi Crown Prince; energy prices surge in the first real sign of a potential easing of the ongoing pricing war and thus saw petro-currencies initially rally with CAD, RUB, MXN, appreciating; weighing on the dollar index slightly. However, later comments from a US and Saudi official walked back on the initial figures, raising eyebrows among participants with regards to the accuracy of Trump's announcement, spurring another bout of risk-off, and DXY to fresh daily highs around 100.41, while also seeing a slight reversal in petro currencies, as energy pared gains. CAD, however, was flat heading into the overnight session and MXN weaker, while the buck was off highs. Analysts at ING highlight the recent strength in the dollar is spurred by USD funding challenges and a “mass exodus in portfolio flows from emerging markets”; it does however argue that the dollar strength is temporary, and expects funding issues to improve over the coming weeks. 

EUR: EURUSD fell victim to the buck strength, once again, and crossed beneath 1.0850 which coincided with DXY reclaiming 100.0. Technicians are keeping an eye on Fib level at 1.0837 to the downside ahead of 1.08 as areas of support. Lloyds FX analysts stated that a move through 1.0835/1.08 would question their bullish outlook, and risks a retesting of the 1.0615-1.05 support region. The bank highlights the continuation of a correction from 1.1170 but they “remain biased that pullbacks are corrective ahead of a further recovery from 1.0635 toward the 1.14-1.15 previous highs”.

GBP: Cable traded between the 1.2351-1.2474 parameters amid a lack of fundamental updates although EURGBP dipped further beneath 0.88 towards its 200dma at 0.8753 and a Fib retracement level at 0.8748. ING thinks GBP is no longer meaningfully suffering in a risk off environment which shows an improvement on the USD funding situation and decline in FX volatility. The desk writes this “makes the external-funding-needs-dependent GBP less vulnerable and leads to a lower currency downside”.

CAD: The loonie initially saw a turnaround from recent weakness amid a nice bounce in oil prices as President Trump expects a deal between Saudi and Russia, while later announcing he expects the two nations to cut production by 10-15mln BPD, a positive sign in the pricing war between the two. However, as both Saudi and US officials walked back on Trump’s announcement a slight reversal was seen in the crude complex and thus in the Loonie, which saw USDCAD flat amid a dollar bid. Scotiabank writes “we rather think USDCAD is carving out a broad range trade between 1.39/1.40 on the downside and 1.45/1.47 on the topside; uncertainty will limit CAD gains while the expanding Fed balance sheet will curb USD strength.” 

AUD: AUD not quite the G10 underperformer today, but took a knock in later trade amid a souring in risk appetite, seeing AUDUSD just off session lows. As the government is about to increase bond issuance to fund its 16% of GDP fiscal package, the RBA may have to increase the size of its balance sheet at a quicker rate in the near term, some have argued. 

JPY/XAU/CHF: Havens were mixed today as the dollar took haven status weighing on JPY amid today’s clouded risk sentiment. Meanwhile, gold continued its rise and reclaimed USD 1,600 to the upside. CHF was firmer against the EUR and around the 1.0550 level, but weaker against the buck given the strength in the greenback. 

EMFX: EM was weaker against a rising dollar, although RUB and TRY were the outliers with the former benefiting from positive developments on the Russia/Saudi oil pricing war which led to a rally in crude prices, while Lira retraced some of the prior day losses after USDTRY hit a record high. MXN initially benefited from the announcement from US President Trump although as officials walked back on the comments slightly, MXN reversed course and was weaker against the USD as the buck caught a bid throughout the remainder of the session.

subject: T-Note (M0) futures settled 3 ticks lower at 138-28+
analysis_details: • The TPLEX was little changed amid a choppy session, albeit tight ranges. Futures spiked higher overnight on the announcement the Fed would be suspending USTs and Federal Deposits from the supplementary leverage ratio, supporting banks in maintaining onto Treasuries, although faded the move during APAC trade. Furthermore, similar to Wednesday’s tape action, the complex was sold into the afternoon where the Fed resumed its Treasury purchases, albeit at a smaller clip of USD 60bln per day (down from USD 75bln), which was likely an influencing factor behind the higher offer-to-cover ratios; a crude spike induced rally in equities likely supported the offer in Treasuries too. Note the curve sold off in a steepener fashion after the Fed carried out its long-end purchases first, as it has been doing in prior sessions, before moving up the curve. The corporate issuance bonanza continued with around ten IG issuers coming to the dollar market, including a USD 19bln 5-parter (5s, 7s, 10s, 20s, 30s) from T-Mobile (TMUS) for its Sprint (S) merger. Signs of a healthier corporate debt market have been felt at the front-end too, where the NY Fed noted AA-rated CP spreads continue to decline; the USD 3-month FRA-OIS spread narrowed by 8bps to 113bps on the session. Looking at the T-Curve at settlement, yields were little changed, with yields within 2bps higher/lower.

subject: FX WRAP: Dollar drive continues amid choppy price action
analysis_details:
• DXY: The dollar index saw a choppy trade. Initial weakness in the morning was pared, with the DXY rising to highs at 100.180 prior to the jobless claims data (which spiked to 6.6mln), which resulted in some initial USD weakness. The reversal post data continued as US President Trump announced he expects a 10-15mln BPD oil production from Russia and Saudi after speaking to the Saudi Crown Prince; energy prices surge in the first real sign of a potential easing of the ongoing pricing war and thus saw petro-currencies initially rally with CAD, RUB, MXN, appreciating; weighing on the dollar index slightly. However, later comments from a US and Saudi official walked back on the initial figures, raising eyebrows among participants with regards to the accuracy of Trump's announcement, spurring another bout of risk-off, and DXY to fresh daily highs around 100.41, while also seeing a slight reversal in petro currencies, as energy pared gains. CAD, however, was flat heading into the overnight session and MXN weaker, while the buck was off highs. Analysts at ING highlight the recent strength in the dollar is spurred by USD funding challenges and a “mass exodus in portfolio flows from emerging markets”; it does however argue that the dollar strength is temporary, and expects funding issues to improve over the coming weeks.  
  • EUR: EURUSD fell victim to the buck strength, once again, and crossed beneath 1.0850 which coincided with DXY reclaiming 100.0. Technicians are keeping an eye on Fib level at 1.0837 to the downside ahead of 1.08 as areas of support. Lloyds FX analysts stated that a move through 1.0835/1.08 would question their bullish outlook, and risks a retesting of the 1.0615-1.05 support region. The bank highlights the continuation of a correction from 1.1170 but they “remain biased that pullbacks are corrective ahead of a further recovery from 1.0635 toward the 1.14-1.15 previous highs”. 
  • GBP: Cable traded between the 1.2351-1.2474 parameters amid a lack of fundamental updates although EURGBP dipped further beneath 0.88 towards its 200dma at 0.8753 and a Fib retracement level at 0.8748. ING thinks GBP is no longer meaningfully suffering in a risk off environment which shows an improvement on the USD funding situation and decline in FX volatility. The desk writes this “makes the external-funding-needs-dependent GBP less vulnerable and leads to a lower currency downside”. 
  •  CAD: The loonie initially saw a turnaround from recent weakness amid a nice bounce in oil prices as President Trump expects a deal between Saudi and Russia, while later announcing he expects the two nations to cut production by 10-15mln BPD, a positive sign in the pricing war between the two. However, as both Saudi and US officials walked back on Trump’s announcement a slight reversal was seen in the crude complex and thus in the Loonie, which saw USDCAD flat amid a dollar bid. Scotiabank writes “we rather think USDCAD is carving out a broad range trade between 1.39/1.40 on the downside and 1.45/1.47 on the topside; uncertainty will limit CAD gains while the expanding Fed balance sheet will curb USD strength.”  
  • AUD: AUD not quite the G10 underperformer today, but took a knock in later trade amid a souring in risk appetite, seeing AUDUSD just off session lows. As the government is about to increase bond issuance to fund its 16% of GDP fiscal package, the RBA may have to increase the size of its balance sheet at a quicker rate in the near term, some have argued.  
  • JPY/XAU/CHF: Havens were mixed today as the dollar took haven status weighing on JPY amid today’s clouded risk sentiment. Meanwhile, gold continued its rise and reclaimed USD 1,600 to the upside. CHF was firmer against the EUR and around the 1.0550 level, but weaker against the buck given the strength in the greenback.  
  • EMFX: EM was weaker against a rising dollar, although RUB and TRY were the outliers with the former benefiting from positive developments on the Russia/Saudi oil pricing war which led to a rally in crude prices, while Lira retraced some of the prior day losses after USDTRY hit a record high. MXN initially benefited from the announcement from US President Trump although as officials walked back on the comments slightly, MXN reversed course and was weaker against the USD as the buck caught a bid throughout the remainder of the session.

analysis_details: • Oil spiked higher by as much as 40% at one moment, supporting the equity complex too, after US President Trump tweeted that he spoke to the Saudi Crown Prince who spoke with Russian President Putin, saying, "I expect & hope that they will be cutting back approximately 10 Million Barrels, and maybe substantially more". Note that Trump followed up the tweet saying the cut could be as much as 15mln bbls, although it is worth noting he did not specify the time frame, i.e. per day/week/month… A Russian Kremlin spokesperson followed up the remarks saying that Putin had not spoke to the Saudi Crown Prince. However, Saudi press reported that, at the request of Trump, the Kingdom is calling for an emergency OPEC+ meeting in efforts to reach a fair oil agreement to stabilise the market. WSJ sources also reported that Saudi is mulling an output cut beneath 9mln BPD if others were to join in; adding that it wants other producers, such as the US, Canada, Mexico and others in G20 to take part in any cuts. A Saudi official, as cited by the WSJ, said the “best-case scenario would be, maybe a six-million-barrels-a-day cut… I’m not sure how he reached those figures or which countries he has in mind.” Furthermore, a US administration official later said the US does not know formal details of Saudi/Russian plans to cut supply and that Trump is not planning on asking domestic producers to agree on a specific cut, highlighting that producers are already cutting output as they run into storage capacity. However, Trump’s remarks gained some added credence after the Texas Railroad Commissioner Sitton tweeted that he had a great conversation with Russia's Energy Minister Novak, where both agreed COVID-19 requires an unprecedented level of international cooperation and that they "Discussed 10mbpd out of global supply"; adding that he looks forward to speaking with Saudi Prince Abdulaziz Bin Salman soon. Overnight, Trump said he thinks Saudi and Russia will make a deal, possibly within a few days, regarding oil production and suggested that he may know how to solve it. The DoE, as previously suggested, announced it will be offering oil producers the option to lease space in the SPR, initially 30mln bbls worth of space but with intention to increase that by another 47mln bbls (which would mark full capacity); DoE expects the first crude deliveries to occur in late April or early May. Meanwhile, global storage capacity draws closer where Africa storage tanks are reportedly reaching their tops amid the flood of supply to the market, while separate industry sources suggest that oil traders are storing as much as 80mln bbls of oil on tankers at sea. China announcing it is to begin purchasing oil for state reserves will provide some relief.

content:
DXY

Only a knee-jerk blip on the latest record weekly US claims figure that exceeded last Thursday’s interim ATH more than 2-fold along with consensus, while surpassing even the gloomiest forecast. The Buck dipped briefly as the data dropped, but quickly rebounded amidst heavy declines in riskier currencies with the index proceeding to target stops just under 100.000 before breaching the psychological level on the way to 100.260.

EUR

The Euro was already propping up the G10 table and fearing the extent of the pandemic’s toll on the bloc, but managed to resist attempts on the 1.0900 handle until the aforementioned US jobs headlines hit. However, Eur/Usd subsequently tumbled below 1.0850 and only found a base inches above Fib support at 1.0837 after the Greenback lost momentum in wake of dire NY business conditions and flat factory orders.

CHF/AUD/JPY/NZD/CAD 

Also undermined by the US Dollar’s more pronounced bounce, with the Franc retreating through 0.9700, Aussie reversing towards 0.6000 and Yen waning again following a closer look at 107.00. Similarly, the Kiwi is struggling to keep tabs on 0.5900 and Loonie is paring best crude inspired gains of 1.4100+ even though oil prices received another huge boost via US President Trump claiming that he expects (and hopes could be the caveat) Saudi Arabia and Russia to agree on a 10-15 bn production reduction compounded by reports that the Kingdom has called for an emergency OPEC+ summit. Note, little reaction to in line Swiss CPI data, but looming comments from SNB’s Maechler and Moser will be monitored given that Eur/Chf is still well under 1.0600.

NOK/RUB/MXN/GBP

The Norwegian Crown has been outperforming for the most part and naturally got more fuel from the aforementioned spike in crude along with fellow WTI and Brent backed counterparts like the Russian Rouble and Mexican Peso. Indeed, Eur/Nok stayed well off near 11.4800 peaks, Usd/Rub recoiled from circa 79.2400 and Usd/Mxn probed sub-24.0000 from 24.5000+ at one stage. Meanwhile, Sterling continued to draw traction from favourable cross winds rather than anything obvious in terms of UK fundamentals, as Eur/Gbp fell further below 0.8800 towards keep technical support (0.8753/48 200 DMA and fib retracement) and Cable pivoted 1.2400.

EM

Starkly contrasting fortunes for the Rand and Lira irrespective of similar concerns weighing on SA and Turkey, with Usd/Zar up to fresh record peaks over 18.6550 vs Usd/Try paring back from 6.7100+.

subject: US equities open slightly firmer after initial decent gains in the futures reversed course after a dismal jobless claims data
analysis_details:
FUTURES: After Wednesday's fall on Wall Street, US equity futures saw decent gains in pre-market action, however gains have reversed and briefly entered negative territory after the dismal jobless claims data which fared worse than all analyst forecast, albeit now trade slightly positive. Overnight, Asia enjoyed a calmer session, and European stocks are currently in the red (with energy outperforming, travel and leisure still underperforming).

SECTORS: Energy stocks are tracking crude prices higher upwards on talk of a truce between Russia/Saudi/US. Financials slightly lower amid lower yields, consumer staples being weighed on by Walgreens (WBA) earnings.

US STOCK NEWS: Walgreens (WBA) saw an EPS beat, although revenue and US Pharmacy SSS fell short of estimates. WBA CFO later stated the co. is to defer some investments, adding some strong sales have slowed and are now declining but it will continue with its share repurchase programme and has no plan to cut its dividend. Boeing (BA) CEO announced the company has initiated voluntary layoffs to respond to current market conditions, allowing employees to exit with some benefits, adding it will continue to drive the safe return to service of the 737 MAX, and it will continue to deliver on its commercial, defense and space programs, and it will be able to meet customer commitments. Ford (F) Q1 total sales fell 12.5% to 516.300 vehicles. Luckin Coffee (LK) are -83% after it announced it has formed a special committee to oversee an internal investigation which found its COO fabricated sales of the financial statements for FY19.

MACRO: Treasuries bid across the curve, dollar index is firmer, and around session highs back above 100; oil is up over 5%, off recent highs. Sentiment however has been hampered after the jobless claims data saw a rise to 6.6mln above the top end of analyst forecasts; Goldman expected 6mln. Today’s weekly data is far more important than Friday’s monthly Employment Situation Report and is a key input into economists’ US economic recession (and recovery) models.

FED OPERATIONS: The Fed will be buying USD 60bln of Treasuries daily on Thursday and Friday, a lower pace than the USD 75bln of daily purchases on Monday to Wednesday. Full schedule of today’s purchases and amounts can be found here.

STOCK VALUATIONS: Perhaps one of the more underreported reasons for the pressure on stocks is due to corporates cutting guidance and dividends a couple of weeks ahead of earnings season. The S&P's forward P/E ratio mean estimate is under 17 now, according to Refinitiv, whereas a few weeks ago it was over 20. UBS says that the index is currently being held-up by lofty P/E in growth stocks; the forward P/E of the high-growth segment has only contracted to 2016 levels thus far, and the bank says this is at odds with P/E in deep value, which suggests that the discounting has scope to run further in the "growthier" parts of the index. UBS says stocks will continue to remain under pressure until earnings expectations find a footing.

Russian Energy Minister Novak says current oil price is not satisfying for anyone; US and Russia agreed on measures to stabilise the oil market; it is wrong for Russia to raise production now; oversupply remains
content:
• Russia can survive through a period of low oil prices
  • US President Trump and Russian President Putin discussed the oil market
  • He sees global oil demand declining 10-15mln BPD; demand could fall 20mln BPD in the next few weeks
  • US ad Russia shares similar views on the oil market
  • OPEC+ cannot counter the declining demand on its own
  • One of the options is to return to talks with Saudi
reaction_details:
• As Novak speaks, WTI keeps gaining ground with intra-day change now surpassing that of Brent which was outperforming earlier in the session
  • The WTI/Brent Arb has also narrowed to ~USD 4.5/bbl from the earlier USD 5/bbl
analysis_details:
• WTI fares modestly better Brent now amid a seemingly growing alliance between US and Russia after sources suggested a US-Saudi partnership has been put on hold, possibly after Saudi refused US’ request to ditch production hikes.
  • Earlier reports noted The US and Russian Energy Ministers, after President Trump and President Putin’s call, agreed to continue the dialogue among major producers and keep tabs on the market volatility
  • Reports yesterday noted that Russia is reportedly ditching its plans to raise production by 300k BPD (with scope for it to be raised to 500k BPD) amid the supply glut
  • US President Trump said he thinks Saudi and Russia will make a deal regarding oil production and suggested that he may know how to solve it. There were also comments from the US Energy Department which urged Saudi Arabia, Russia and others to work together to calm oil markets, while it noted it is frustrating that Saudi and Russia are boosting production and do not advance shared interests in stable markets. (Newswires)
  • Russia's President Putin said Russia and other oil producers and consumers should find solutions that improve the oil market situation. (Interfax)
  • Senior Gulf source said Saudi Arabia supports cooperation among oil producers to stabilize oil markets and that oil market turmoil was caused by Russia opposition to OPEC+ cuts at the meeting in early March. (Newswires)

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1400BST/0800CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

  • Of note for Airlines (AAL, DAL, LUV, UAL), the US Treasury is reportedly planning on hiring three Wall Street banks to advise it on providing tens of billions of dollars to aid the airline industry, according to WSJ.

DOW JONES

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) announced it has reduced its 30% tax of payments when video apps on its platform sold TV shows and movies. Elsewhere, Tile Inc, told a panel in congress that Apple failed to live up to its promises which would resolve the dispute between the two companies, noting its anticompetitive behavior has gotten worse, not better.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) CEO announced the company has initiated voluntary layoffs to respond to current market conditions, allowing employees to exit with some benefits, adding it will continue to drive the safe return to service of the 737 MAX, and it will continue to deliver on its commercial, defense and space programs, and it will be able to meet customer commitments. This followed from WSJ reports that it is to begin early retirement and buyout packages to its employees as the coronavirus pandemic weighs on the airline industry.
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced it will reschedule its 2020 Medical Devices Business review to protect the health and safety of its employees.
  • Merck & Co. (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) Phase 3 KEYNOTE-177 trial evaluating its Keytruda, an anti PD-1 therapy, met one of its dual primary end points of progression free survival.
  • Merck & Co. (MRK), Pfizer (PFE) & Eli Lilly (LLY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced medical volunteer service programs, which allows licensed medical professionals to help against the coronavirus.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) announced its Disney+ content will be available in the Middle East and North Africa on OSN from April 9th.
  • Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) (Consumer Staples/Drug Retail) Q2 20 (USD): Adj EPS 1.52 (exp. 1.46); revenue 35bln (exp. 35.3bln). WBA Q2 US pharmacy SSS +2.7% (exp. +2.8%). PRIMER: US weekly initial jobless claims due at 1330 BST/0830 ET; Street expects a new record high, potentially 6mln some think
content:
• Expectations are for 3.5mln in the week of 22-28 March (range 1.5mln to 6mln) against the prior 3.28mln (which was a record high). Continuing claims (an important signal in GDP models) is expected to print 4.88mln (range 4.5mln to 5mln) from last week's 1.80mln).
  • This week's initial jobless claims data takes on a more timely signal about the labour market than Friday's nonfarm payrolls data for March, and will be more relevant for econometric models that attempt to forecast recessions. It is also key in assessing how deep recessions will be and when the recovery is expected to begin.
  • Another important note is that weekly jobless claims data are based on "hard facts", UBS points out, unlike survey data which is subject to quirks around a) some of the treatment of supply chains, which has flattered data, b) the fact that many respondents will not be replying to surveys during the virus disruption period, and c) survey data will give more accurate assessments during 'normal' times, perhaps not as much in unusual times.
  • Goldman Sachs, which looks for initial jobless claims to print 6mln in the week, says it expects claims to remain elevated in the weeks ahead, with nearly 18mln "excess" claims by the end of April. GS highlights the importance of today's data for GDP modelling: "We estimate that the percent hit to the level of real GDP relative to trend will be roughly equal to excess initial claims in millions divided by 1.5," adding that "a peak in continuing claims should signal that GDP has stabilised, while sharp declines in continuing claims will be the best signal that GDP is recovering."
  • Some desks have also noted the potential lack of upside for markets from today's release, since a below expected/not as bad as feared print may be disregarded as a by-product of incomplete data, or there being further turmoil ahead regardless. Whilst an above expected/worse than feared print will add to the narrative that the US labour market is due for a tumultuous out-turn, which could prompt analysts to further revise higher their calls for the unemployment rate.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 2nd April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are currently printing modest gains but US futures are notably firmer than their EU counterpart
  • Crude is bolstered after constructive remarks from Trump and reports that China are to begin purchasing oil for state reserves after the recent price crash
  • Fed exempted US Treasury debt and Federal Reserve deposits from supplementary leverage ratio for one year as it seeks to ease strains in Treasury market
  • EU Commission proposes borrowing EUR 100bln against EU government guarantees to finance the EU short-time work scheme
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Initial Jobless Claims, ISM New York Index & Business Conditions, Canadian Trade Balance, SNB’s Maechler & Moser

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Spanish coronavirus cases stand at 110,240 (Prev. 102,136), deaths increase by 950 to 10,003 (Prev. 9,053). (Newswires)

US President Trump said during the coronavirus task force daily press briefing that we are going to have a couple weeks that will be rough, while Trump responded that we are looking at the whole thing when asked about curtailing domestic flights. (Newswires)

US Treasury Department said US Social Security recipients will automatically receive coronavirus economic impact payments, while there were separate reports that the US Treasury Department is planning to hire Wall St advisers to advise on providing aid to the airline sector from the recently approved USD 2tln stimulus bill. (Newswires/WSJ)

EU's Economics Commissioner Gentiloni states that annual GDP growth declines by 3% each month in a lockdown - there are no discussions regarding a bailout for Italy. (Newswires)

Australian PM Morrison said we are slowing the spread of coronavirus and that Parliament will return next Wednesday. PM Morrison added it is not known when social restrictions can be relaxed and there were also separate reports that lockdown laws will be in place for 90 days in New South Wales which is Australia's largest state by population. (Newswires)

Omani oil minister says the country is not held by commitments to reduce output after March 31st, does not support increasing oil output at this sensitive stage. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed after a weak handover from Wall St where stocks extended on the prior quarter’s historical rout to finish the day with losses of more than 4% and the DJIA suffered a near 1000-point drop amid ongoing coronavirus fears. ASX 200 (-1.98%) was dragged lower by its top-weighted financials sector after the RBNZ ordered all banks in New Zealand to suspend dividends which pressured Australia’s big 4 that have operations across the Tasman and amid concerns there could be similar restrictions domestically, with airline shares also in a tailspin after the government denied Virgin Australia’s request for a loan and indicated it would not provide the Co. with a bailout. ASX 200 (-1.98%) was was also downbeat but off lows as the JPY-risk dynamic remained the main driver for Tokyo sentiment and with automakers lacklustre following abysmal monthly sales updates. Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.69%) initially struggled for direction amid the broad cautiousness and after PBoC liquidity inaction, while tensions with the US also risk flaring up as the latter is to tighten rules to prevent China from obtaining US tech for commercial purposes that could also be applied for military use and following US intelligence reports that alleged China concealed the coronavirus outbreak and underreported the number of cases and deaths. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially continued its pullback to below 152.50 with demand sapped heading into the 10yr JGB auction, although prices the rebounded on return from the lunch break and following mixed results in the 10yr auction which was mixed but still showed a jump in the b/c and minimal tail in price.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0995 vs. Exp. 7.0949 (Prev. 7.0771)

US is to tighten rules to prevent China from obtaining US tech for commercial purposes that could also be applied for military use. (Newswires)

Japanese Gov't are to offer JPY 100bln in financial support to large Co's through the Development Bank of Japan, according to the Nikkei. (Nikkei)

US

Fed exempted US Treasury debt and Federal Reserve deposits from supplementary leverage ratio for one year as it seeks to ease strains in Treasury market and boost banks' ability to provide credit. (Newswires)

UK/EU

EU Commission proposes borrowing EUR 100bln against EU government guarantees to finance the EU short-time work scheme, according to a document. (Newswires)

-          Urges a quick resolution on a new long-term budget that would support the recovery from epidemic effects; states that there will be no national co-financing requirement for any of the EU's cohesion funds

-          Subsequently, EU Commission President Von der Leyen says that the Gov't heads she spoke to are interested and positive in regards to the short-term work proposal, says EUR 100bln short-term scheme is a massive support; adds that the invention of new tools would take too long to agree among member states for use in the current crisis

French Finance Minister Le Maire says Europe should utilise all means available in response to the virus, adding that we should use ESM with light conditionality and no stigma attached; he favour activating new financing from EIB for EUR 200bln.  (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo tweeted that reports Iranian diplomats were involved in an assassination of a dissident in Turkey are disturbing but consistent with their assignments, while he added that Iran's "diplomats" are agents of terror and have conducted multiple assassinations and bomb plots in Europe in the past decade. (Twitter)

EQUITIES

European stocks attempt to clamber from yesterday’s steep losses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.4%) after sentiment somewhat improved in APAC trade following a downbeat session on Wall Street. Bourses see modest broad-based gains, with Netherland’s AEX (+1.2%) leading the pack – propped up by Shell’s (+9%) Dutch listing and with ABN AMRO (+8.3%) and ING Groep (+1.8%) rebounding from the broad downside seen in banks yesterday. Meanwhile, US equity futures see more pronounced gains with the contracts higher to the tune of 2%. Sector-wise, Energy significantly outperforms – led by the price action in the oil complex as President Trump voiced optimism regarding a Saudi/Russia resolution, whilst demand from China keeps the sector underpinned. Other sectors are broadly mixed with underperformance seen in IT and Utility names – sectors do not reflect a specific risk tone. Travel & Leisure reside at the bottom of the pack as it feels no reprieve from the demand destruction caused by the virus outbreak. In terms of movers, the top of the Stoxx 600 was initially largely dominated by oil and gas names with Aker BP, Subsea losing steam as trade went underway whilst Tullow Oil (+8.0%), BP (+5.5%) and Shell remain among the top gainers. IAG (+2.5%) sees upside amid reports that the Co’s British Airways is nearing a deal to suspend 36k workers given the impact of operations from COVID-19. On the flip side; Carnival (-8.6%) sees pressure after S&P cut its rating to “BBB-“ from “BBB; the lowest investment grade level. Centrica (-7.4%) is weighed on by dividend and guidance suspensions coupled with the interruption of its Spirit Energy divestment. Elsewhere, Handelsblatt reported that the heads of Daimler (+1.0%), BMW (+3%) and Volkswagen (+1.0%) had a conversation with German Chancellor Merkel in which they wanted to explore how the corporations can rekindle production. The auto makers also raised worries regarding supply chains and expressed great concern regarding Southern Europe. On that note, Fiat Chrysler (-1.0%) slid at the open after Italy reported car registrations slumping 85.4% YY in March amid the lockdown measures in the country.

NOK/SEK/CAD/NZD/AUD - The Norwegian Krona and its Scandinavian partner are forging more gains on a combination of constructive technical factors, Euro underperformance and a recovery in oil prices prompted by China replenishing crude reserves at cheaper levels and US President Trump expressing confidence about resolving the spat between Russia and Saudi Arabia. Eur/Nok has been down below 11.2000 and Eur/Sek sub-10.9350, with the former also gleaning encouragement from ramped up Norges Bank selling of foreign currencies in April. Elsewhere, the Kiwi and Aussie are consolidating off recent lows amidst less volatile trading conditions than seen of late, with Nzd/Usd holding firmly above 0.5900 and Aud/Usd not far from 0.6100 against the backdrop of relatively stable risk sentiment and Moody’s reaffirming NZ’s top notch triple A rating.

EUR/CHF/JPY - As noted above, the single currency remains under pressure across board as COVID-19 cases and deaths continue to rise in the Euro area, while chart impulses turn more bearish after shallower rebounds in Eur/Usd and even Eur/GBP despite the UK also suffering mounting nCoV infections and fatalities. Indeed, the headline pair has not been able to revisit 1.1000 and looks more prone to relinquishing 1.0900, while the cross is capped beneath 0.8800 after waning well short of 0.8900. Meanwhile, US equity futures see more pronounced gains with the contracts higher to the tune of 2%. Sector-wise, Energy significantly outperforms – led by the price action in the oil complex as President Trump voiced optimism regarding a Saudi/Russia resolution, whilst demand from China keeps the sector underpinned. Other sectors are broadly mixed with underperformance seen in IT and Utility names – sectors do not reflect a specific risk tone. Travel & Leisure reside at the bottom of the pack as it feels no reprieve from the demand destruction caused by the virus outbreak. In terms of movers, the top of the Stoxx 600 was initially largely dominated by oil and gas names with Aker BP, Subsea losing steam as trade went underway whilst Tullow Oil (+8.0%), BP (+5.5%) and Shell remain among the top gainers. FIXED INCOME

Although the tide has turned again for Gilt futures, the 10 year benchmark has pared more early Liffe losses and briefly clambered back above parity, at 136.86 (+2 ticks vs -48 ticks at worst) in wake of another solid DMO sale, as bids exceeded the previous ratio for 2041 issuance even though the yield was around half the level when last auctioned in January. The more pronounced rebound also filtered through to Bunds and US Treasuries to an extent, although the former remains deep in negative territory after hitting a new Eurex base (171.60 and almost a full point underwater), while the latter is only a few ticks above 139-00 compared to 139-14+ at best. Ahead, all eyes on weekly US claims above all else, aside from breaking virus news of course.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures rebound with a vengeance following yesterday’s deterioration, with upside initially emanating from optimism expressed by US President Trump regarding a Russia/Saudi resolution, whilst gains were exacerbated on reports that China is in the market to purchase cheap oil.  Upon the initial announcement, WTI futures rose above USD 22/bbl after a settlement at USD 20.31/bbl. Brent gained over 10% with prices now north of USD 27/bbl before testing Tuesday’s USD 27.85-90/bbl high. Both contracts have waned off intra-day best levels. The spread between the contracts also widens to USD 5/bbl from the prior days USD 4.40/bbl.  Despite the confidence regarding the OPEC+ feud, markets are yet to see a discernible move of reconciliation between Saudi and Russia. Hence, Saudi Aramco OSPs expected to be released on Sunday will be key to gauge whether Saudi maintains its stance in the dispute. Meanwhile, sources reported that China is to utilise the cheap oil prices to fill up emergency reserves, although much speculation will surround this as the Chinese government is unwilling to release information regarding the size, formation or use of its emergency stockpiles. Elsewhere, spot gold continues to recoups losses seen on Tuesday with the yellow metal back below its 21 DMA (USD 1587.40/oz), having earlier failed to convincingly top USD 1600/oz. Copper meanwhile mirrors overall risk-sentiment and edges higher, albeit the red metal remains contained within recent ranges above USD 2/lb. Finally, Shanghai steel futures slid over 3% as it tracked declines in iron ore amid weaker demand prospects from the virus outbreak – with car sales a key gauge of steel demand.

content: • Link
analysis_details:
• Moody's expects the New Zealand economy to remain resilient in the face of shocks, given its trade openness, diverse and competitive agricultural export base, flexible labor and product markets, high wealth levels, and favorable demographics, driven by robust migration trends. 
  • These attributes support New Zealand's medium-term growth potential of around 2.5-3.0%, a level higher than many advanced economy Aaa-rated peers.

subject: Russia has no plans to lift oil production amid oversupply in the market
content: • Has not ruled out discussing the situation with Saudi Arabia
analysis_details:
• This is a reiteration of recent commentary from Russia's Kremlin
  • Earlier last month, Russia noted that companies will raise production by 300k BPD with scope for it to be raised to 500k BPD
  • This follows the call between the US and Russian President yesterday in which the leaders discussed the oil price rot - the leaders agreed on the importance of stability in the oil market
  • The US and Russian Energy Ministers, after President Trump and President Putin’s call, agreed to continue the dialogue among major producers and keep tabs on the market volatility
  • REMINDER: the move by Saudi to ramp up production and cut OSPs follows the collapse in ties with Russia after Moscow refused to yield to Saudi’s 1.5mln BPD output curb proposal but instead vied to extend the current cuts. The Kingdom hopes the slump in oil prices and the expected diminishing in Russia’s market shares will prompt Moscow back to the negotiating table and force its hand to cut output.

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
2nd April 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BSTT/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed after a weak handover from Wall St where stocks extended on the prior quarter’s historical rout to finish the day with losses of more than 4% and the DJIA suffered a near 1000-point drop amid ongoing coronavirus fears. ASX 200 (-1.3%) was dragged lower by its top-weighted financials sector after the RBNZ ordered all banks in New Zealand to suspend dividends which pressured Australia’s big 4 that have operations across the Tasman and amid concerns there could be similar restrictions domestically, with airline shares also in a tailspin after the government denied Virgin Australia’s request for a loan and indicated it would not provide the Co. with a bailout. Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) was also downbeat but off lows as the JPY-risk dynamic remained the main driver for Tokyo sentiment and with automakers lacklustre following abysmal monthly sales updates. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) struggled for direction amid the broad cautiousness and after PBoC liquidity inaction, while tensions with the US also risk flaring up as the latter is to tighten rules to prevent China from obtaining US tech for commercial purposes that could also be applied for military use and following US intelligence reports that alleged China concealed the coronavirus outbreak and underreported the number of cases and deaths.

FTSE 100

NMC Health (NMC LN) – ADCB Bank has more than USD 1bln of exposure in NMC Health, according to sources. The bank is deeply concerned about Co’s recent announcement of undisclosed liabilities. Sources added that some lenders are in talks to set up a committee to discuss ideas on how to recover funds from NMC. (Newswires)

WM Morrison (MRW LN) – UK’s highest court has ruled that the Co. is not liable after a former employee was responsible for leaking payroll data of 100k employees. (Newswires)

IAG (IAG LN) - British Airways is set to suspend 36,000 workers given the impact on operations from COVID-19. (Telegraph)

UK Companies – Around half of UK companies are looking to place their staff on furlough, due to the coronavirus, according to a Chambers of Commerce survey. (FT)

Marks & Spencer (MSK LN) – Frontline staff are to receive a 15% bonus for their work during the virus period. (Newswires)

EX-DIVS: InterContinental Hotels (IHG LN), Mondi (MNDI LN), Melrose Industries (MRO LN), Phoenix Group (PHNX LN), Standard Life Aberdeen (SLA LN), Smith & Nephew (SN/ LN) and Taylor Wimpey (TW LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 5.05 points off the FTSE 100. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Autotrader (AUTO LN) – Co. has raised GBP 186mln after issuing shares worth an additional 5% of their stock with institutions. (Times)

BROKER MOVES

HIKMA PHARMACEUTICALS (HIK LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Co. is said to have reached a deal with pilot union regarding wage suppot through government programmes. Separately, Co. is planning to send 66% of its workforce (around 87k workers) on short-time work. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Commerzbank (CBK GY) – Co. is reportedly working on concrete steps to reduce costs. The Bain consultancy is looking as ways the save the bank EUR 500mln, according to sources. Bain has already identified ways to save EUR 350mln with the bank potentially cutting spending in the real estate sector. (WiWo)

Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 2nd April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·        Asian equity markets traded mixed after a weak handover from Wall St where stocks finished the day with losses of more than 4%

·        DXY relatively steady overnight with the greenback’s major counterparts contained ahead of weekly jobs figures from the US

·        US President Trump is to meet with the CEOs of US oil companies on Friday to talk about helping the industry

·        Fed exempted US Treasury debt and Federal Reserve deposits from supplementary leverage ratio for one year as it seeks to ease strains in Treasury market

·        US CDC said COVID-19 cases rose +14% to 186,101 (prev. +16% to 163,539) and the death toll rose 26% to 3,603 (prev. +19% to 2,860)

·        Looking ahead, highlights include Swiss CPI, US Initial Jobless Claims. ISM New York Index & Business Conditions, Canadian Trade Balance, SNB’s Maechler & Moser, supply from Spain, France, & UK

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US CDC said COVID-19 cases rose +14% to 186,101 (prev. +16% to 163,539) and the death toll rose 26% to 3,603 (prev. +19% to 2,860). (Newswires)

US President Trump said during the coronavirus task force daily press briefing that we are going to have a couple weeks that will be rough, while Trump responded that we are looking at the whole thing when asked about curtailing domestic flights. (Newswires)

US Treasury Department said US Social Security recipients will automatically receive coronavirus economic impact payments, while there were separate reports that the US Treasury Department is planning to hire Wall St advisers to advise on providing aid to the airline sector from the recently approved USD 2tln stimulus bill. (Newswires/WSJ)

US House Speaker Pelosi said the House should be able to move on to the infrastructure bill shortly after the planned return to session on April 20th, while she added the plan is similar to the USD 760bln over five years announced in January but there could be changes. (Newswires)

UK Defence Ministry said UK reservists are to be mobilised for an initial 6 months to provide medical and logistical support for the health service, according to a statement. (Newswires)

Australian PM Morrison said we are slowing the spread of coronavirus and that Parliament will return next Wednesday. PM Morrison added it is not known when social restrictions can be relaxed and there were also separate reports that lockdown laws will be in place for 90 days in New South Wales which is Australia's largest state by population. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed after a weak handover from Wall St where stocks extended on the prior quarter’s historical rout to finish the day with losses of more than 4% and the DJIA suffered a near 1000-point drop amid ongoing coronavirus fears. ASX 200 (-1.3%) was dragged lower by its top-weighted financials sector after the RBNZ ordered all banks in New Zealand to suspend dividends which pressured Australia’s big 4 that have operations across the Tasman and amid concerns there could be similar restrictions domestically, with airline shares also in a tailspin after the government denied Virgin Australia’s request for a loan and indicated it would not provide the Co. with a bailout. Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) was also downbeat but off lows as the JPY-risk dynamic remained the main driver for Tokyo sentiment and with automakers lacklustre following abysmal monthly sales updates. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) struggled for direction amid the broad cautiousness and after PBoC liquidity inaction, while tensions with the US also risk flaring up as the latter is to tighten rules to prevent China from obtaining US tech for commercial purposes that could also be applied for military use and following US intelligence reports that alleged China concealed the coronavirus outbreak and underreported the number of cases and deaths. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially continued its pullback to below 152.50 with demand sapped heading into the 10yr JGB auction, although prices the rebounded on return from the lunch break and following mixed results in the 10yr auction which was mixed but still showed a jump in the b/c and minimal tail in price.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0995 vs. Exp. 7.0949 (Prev. 7.0771)

US is to tighten rules to prevent China from obtaining US tech for commercial purposes that could also be applied for military use. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Sunak is to announce an overhaul of the Business Interruption Loans Scheme to remove a key obstacle for SMEs that struggle to access it. In related news, UK Business Minister Sharma said the Chancellor will announce more related to business support schemes in the coming days. (Sky News/Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, this week’s safe-haven bid that had spurred the DXY back above the 99.00 level has petered out although the pullback is limited with overnight price action stuck around the 99.50 level as participants await the latest US jobless claims data later today ahead of Friday’s NFP figures. The greenback’s major counterparts were also uneventful overnight with EUR/USD contained below 1.0950 and in proximity to several hourly moving average levels including its 200-Hour MA at 1.0927, while GDP/USD languished beneath resistance at 1.2400 where there is a small option expiry of GBP 210mln at 1.2390 set to roll off at today’s New York cut. Elsewhere, USD/JPY attempted to nurse some of the recent losses after support held at 107.00 and antipodeans were lacklustre due to the subdued risk tone, weaker PBoC reference rate and poor Quarterly NAB Business Confidence data for Australia.

Australian NAB Business Confidence (Q1) -11 (Prev. -1). (Newswires)

RBNZ called on banks to freeze dividends, while it is to also unveil a term lending facility which will launch next month and plans a longer-term funding scheme for the banking system. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with oil prices recouping some recent loss ground to lift WTI crude futures back above the USD 21.00/bbl level following optimistic comments by US President Trump who thinks Saudi and Russia will reach an agreement regarding output and with President Trump to also meet the chiefs of US oil firms tomorrow to discuss potential supportive action. Elsewhere, gold was flat as it mirrored the similar uneventful trade in the greenback, while copper was slightly choppy as early weakness was reversed after finding support at the USD 2.15/lb level.

US President Trump said he thinks Saudi and Russia will make a deal regarding oil production and suggested that he may know how to solve it. There were also comments from the US Energy Department which urged Saudi Arabia, Russia and others to work together to calm oil markets, while it noted it is frustrating that Saudi and Russia are boosting production and do not advance shared interests in stable markets. (Newswires)

US President Trump is to meet with the CEOs of US oil companies (XOM, CVX, OXY) on Friday to talk about helping the industry and will discuss potential for aid such as tariffs on imports from Saudi, according to sources. (WSJ)

Russia's President Putin said Russia and other oil producers and consumers should find solutions that improve the oil market situation. (Interfax)

Senior Gulf source said Saudi Arabia supports cooperation among oil producers to stabilize oil markets and that oil market turmoil was caused by Russia opposition to OPEC+ cuts at the meeting in early March. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump stated they are upon information and belief Iran or its proxies are planning a sneak attack on US troops and/or assets in Iraq, while he warned Iran will pay a very heavy price if this happens. In related news, an official noted that US intelligence threads have been building for some time on a potential Iran-backed attack against the US in Iraq and that an Iran-backed attack on US personnel in Iraq would likely be deniable, as opposed to state-on-state, while there were also reports that Iranian Supreme Leader Khamenei advisor warned the US of consequences of "provocative actions" in Iraq. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo tweeted that reports Iranian diplomats were involved in an assassination of a dissident in Turkey are disturbing but consistent with their assignments, while he added that Iran's "diplomats" are agents of terror and have conducted multiple assassinations and bomb plots in Europe in the past decade. (Twitter)

US

The TPLEX flattened amid a stock sell-off and issuance weighted towards the front. The T-Note caught its bid overnight and faded off its highs as Europeans left for the session. Desks noted that real money remained an aggressive seller into the Fed’s buy-back operations, where the T-Note rolled lower in the later part of the session alongside a high offer-to-cover ratio in the Fed’s 7- to 20-year maturity operation, perhaps a signal participants are happier to sell their UST holdings at these rates. It also may be ahead of Thursday, where the Fed will taper back its UST purchases from USD 75bln to 60bln a day, where there could be some front-running any perceived sell-off as the Fed begins to step back. Furthermore, corporates continue to swamp the issuance channels, including some European’s coming to the Dollar market on Wednesday – USD 6bln from AB InBev (10s, 20s, 30s, 40s) and USD 5bln from Equinor (5s, 7s, 10s, 20s, 30s). Elsewhere, note that the Fed’s RRP saw a fall in demand to USD 207.83bln across less counterparties, coinciding with slightly firmer GC rates, while the regular O/N repo operation in the morning saw zero bids, and a marginal amount in the afternoon. By settlement the curve was flatter, 2s unch. at 0.23%, 10s -6.5bps at 0.63%, 30s -6.5bps at 1.29%. T-note (M0) futures settled 9+ ticks higher at 138-31+.

Fed exempted US Treasury debt and Federal Reserve deposits from supplementary leverage ratio for one year as it seeks to ease strains in Treasury market and boost banks' ability to provide credit. (Newswires)

Fed's Rosengren (non-voter, hawk) said he expects the unemployment rate to rise dramatically and that the virus will impact home and commercial real estate prices, while he added that if restrictions continue for too long, it will increase the distress among highly leveraged companies. (Newswires)
