Asia equity markets are mixed after a weak handover from Wall St where stocks extended on the prior quarter’s historical rout to finish the day with losses of more than 4% amid ongoing coronavirus fears, in which the DJIA suffered a near-1000 point drop. ASX 200 (-2.1%) is dragged lower by its top-weighted financials sector after the RBNZ ordered all banks in the country to suspend dividends which pressured Australia’s big 4 that have operations across the Tasman and amid concerns there could be similar restrictions domestically, with airline shares also in a tailspin after the government denied Virgin Australia’s request for a loan and indicated it would not provide the Co. with a bailout. Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) is also downbeat but off lows as the JPY-risk dynamic remains the main driver for Tokyo sentiment and with automakers lacklustre following abysmal monthly sales updates, while Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) struggle for direction amid the broad cautiousness and after PBoC liquidity inaction. In addition, tensions with the US also risk flaring up as the US is to tighten rules to prevent China from obtaining US tech for commercial purposes that could also be applied for military use and following US intelligence reports that alleged China concealed the coronavirus outbreak and underreported the number of cases and deaths.

In FX markets, this week’s safe-haven bid that had spurred the DXY back above the 99.00 level has petered out although the pullback is limited with overnight price action stuck around the 99.50 level as participants await the latest US jobless claims data later today ahead of Friday’s NFP figures. Elsewhere, USD/JPY attempts to nurse some of the recent losses after support held at 107.00 and antipodeans are lacklustre due to the subdued risk tone, weaker PBoC reference rate and poor Quarterly NAB Business Confidence data for Australia.

Finally, 10yr JGBs failed to benefit from the negative risk tone in Tokyo and continued its pullback to below 152.50, with demand sapped heading into the latest 10yr auction due later.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: China’s Yunnan Province is to bar citizens from leaving China to prevent the spread of coronavirus, while a county in the Henan province instituted a partial lockdown
content:
Shangri-La Asia (69 HK) - Co. is to shut its Bangkok and Chiang Mai hotels for 1 month. (Newswires)

Union Medical Healthcare (2138 HK) - Co. guides FY rev. to be at least flat Y/Y. (Newswires)

Yida China (3639 HK) - Co. CFO resigned with immediate effect. (Newswires)

Automakers - China is said to mull reducing EV rebates by 10% and tightening qualifications. (Newswires)

IPOs - China is said to lower the wait time for IPO review of companies related to coronavirus. (Newswires)

Trade - US is to tighten rules to prevent China from obtaining US tech for commercial purposes that could also be applied for military use. (Newswires)

PBoC - PBoC said it conducted CNY 100bln in MLF operations and CNY 30.6bln in Standing Lending Facility operations during March, while it did not conduct any Pledged Supplementary Lending last month. (Newswires)

Other News - Chinese President Xi said they will ensure normal economic and trade activities, while he reiterated that the domestic economy faces challenges due to the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

Coronavirus Updates

China’s Yunnan Province is to bar citizens from leaving China to prevent the spread of coronavirus, while a county in the Henan province instituted a partial lockdown after new coronavirus cases were discovered. (Newswires)

Chinese scientists claimed they have found “extremely effective” antibodies in their efforts to come up with drugs to treat and even prevent the coronavirus according to a report. The team at Beijing’s Tsinghua University was said to have isolated several antibodies that can block the virus that causes COVID-19 from entering human cells, while they are now working to identify the most powerful antibodies and possibly combining them to mitigate the risk of the new coronavirus mutating. (NY Post)

China military scientists hope to test coronavirus vaccine overseas and the first-stage clinical trials will be published this month. (SCMP)

US intelligence community submitted a report to the White House that alleged China concealed the coronavirus outbreak and underreported the number of cases and deaths, while the report also alleged other countries including Egypt, Iran, Indonesia, North Korea, Russia and Saudi Arabia of underreporting their coronavirus numbers. (Newswires)
